entry.title: Flood Advisory issued July 10 at 3:09AM AKDT until July 10 at 9:30PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by a glacier-dammed lake outburst continues.
* WHERE...The Salmon River near areas around mile marker 9 of the Salmon River highway.
* WHEN...Until 930 PM AKDT Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. River or stream flows are elevated.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1045 PM AKDT, a trained weather spotter reported that the river water is murky and muddy, flowing quickly, and about 4 ft above its normal level. Spotter further reported that the water levels had been rising quickly with the river flow getting rougher and making surf/waves in its flow with trees on the edge of the riverbank starting to erode into the river. This indicates that a glacier-dammed lake outburst in areas around mile marker 9 of the Salmon River highway is occurring. Water is not crossing over the road at this time. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly, especially near the Salmon River. - Inherent uncertainty in initial glacier lake volume will result in varying crest height and timing.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include... Hyder.
entry.cap:areaDesc: City of Hyder

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY FOR A GLACIER-DAMMED LAKE OUTBURST REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 930 PM AKDT THIS EVENING

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued July 10 at 3:09AM AKDT until July 11 at 11:45AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
An incoming weather system will spread rain into the southern panhandle starting Thursday afternoon with gusty winds of 25 to 35 mph possible. Heaviest rainfall rate will be Thursday evening to early Friday morning.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Ward Lake near areas near the Ward Lake recreational area.
* WHEN...Until 1145 AM AKDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 258 AM AKDT, river gauge reports indicate water levels on Ward Lake remain steady. An approaching system will bring heavy rain across the area on Thursday with minor flooding expected to begin by Thursday night and early Friday morning, especially near Ward Lake. Rainfall amounts of 1.5 to 2.25 inches are possible. Forecast crest height near 252.0 ft by Friday morning, entering flood stage.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Ketchikan Gateway Borough

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 1145 AM AKDT FRIDAY

This includes Interstate 80 between mile markers 299 and 328.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued July 10 at 6:36AM EDT until July 10 at 11:17AM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Delaware...
White Clay Creek Near Newark affecting New Castle County.
For the White Clay Creek...including Newark...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...White Clay Creek near Newark.
* WHEN...Until late this morning.
* IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, Flooding begins into adjacent open fields. At 13.3 feet, Delaware Route 7, Stanton Christiana Road, begins to flood. At 13.5 feet, Businesses on Delaware Route 7 begin to flood.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 6:15 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 14.2 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 6:15 AM EDT Thursday was 14.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage this morning and continue falling to 4.5 feet tomorrow afternoon. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 14.2 feet on 11/30/2020. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: New Castle, DE

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE THIS MORNING

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued July 10 at 5:36AM CDT until July 11 at 1:00AM CDT by NWS Tulsa OK
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Tulsa has issued a Flood Advisory for the following rivers in Arkansas...
Arkansas River at Ozark Lock and Dam affecting Logan, Franklin and Johnson Counties.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...Arkansas River at Ozark Lock and Dam.
* WHEN...From early this morning to just after midnight tonight.
* IMPACTS...At 355.5 feet, the river remains in its banks, but access to Okane Island may be cut off. At 357.0 feet, flooding affects agricultural use lands along the river downstream of the lock and dam in Franklin County. Gas fields are also subject to flooding downstream. Equipment and livestock should be moved to higher ground. North 5th Street in Logan County near the Six Mile Levee begins to flood and may cut off access to a nearby residence.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 5:00 AM CDT Thursday the stage was 356.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to continue to fall below action stage by late this afternoon. - Action stage is 355.5 feet. - Flood stage is 357.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Franklin, AR; Johnson, AR; Logan, AR

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued July 10 at 6:01AM EDT until July 10 at 9:00AM EDT by NWS Boston/Norton MA
entry.summary:
FFWBOX
The National Weather Service in Norton has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Eastern Worcester County in central Massachusetts... Norfolk County in eastern Massachusetts... Southwestern Suffolk County in eastern Massachusetts... Southeastern Middlesex County in northeastern Massachusetts... Northwestern Bristol County in southeastern Massachusetts... Northwestern Plymouth County in southeastern Massachusetts...
* Until 900 AM EDT.
* At 601 AM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 0.5 and 1 inch of rain has fallen. The expected rainfall rate is 1 to 2 inches in 1 hour. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Boston, Brockton, Quincy, Newton, Brookline, Weymouth, Braintree, Natick, Randolph, Franklin, Needham, North Attleborough, Norwood, Milford, Milton, Stoughton, Attleboro, Dedham, Walpole and Mansfield.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued July 10 at 4:31AM CDT by NWS Chicago IL
entry.summary:
Patchy dense fog will continue to develop near and south of Interstate 80 this morning. Visibility may range from a few miles to less than one quarter of a mile over short distances, leading to hazardous driving conditions. Visibility worsens along and south of the Kankakee River Valley, where a Dense Fog Advisory is in effect until 9 AM.
If traveling this morning, be prepared for rapid changes in visibilities over very short distances, make sure to slow down, and keep plenty of stopping distance between yourself and other vehicles.
If visibilities down to one quarter mile become widespread across the Special Weather Statement area, the Dense Fog Advisory currently to the south may be expanded.
entry.cap:areaDesc: La Salle; Kendall; Grundy; Southern Cook; Northern Will; Southern Will; Eastern Will; Lake; Porter

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued July 10 at 4:18AM CDT by NWS Lincoln IL
entry.summary:
Patchy dense fog has formed across areas northeast of I-74 and in far southeast IL, and will see more dense fog develop along and east of a Galesburg to Lincoln to Effingham line through daybreak. The visibility may fall to a quarter mile or less at times early this morning, leading to potentially hazardous travel conditions. The fog should burn off between 8 and 9 am.
Be sure to slow down if you encounter dense fog and allow extra time to reach your destination. Use low beam headlights if driving, and leave plenty of distance between you and the vehicle ahead.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued July 9 at 5:03PM PDT by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...The South Coast AQMD has updated an air quality alert due to harmful levels of ozone pollution.
* WHERE...In Metropolitan Los Angeles, the San Fernando Valley, Santa Clarita, and the San Gabriel Mountains. Levels of ozone pollution can vary by time and location depending on emissions and air pollution transport.
* WHEN...Until Thursday at 800 PM PDT. The highest ozone levels typically occur in the afternoon and early-evening hours.
* IMPACTS...Ozone air pollution can cause serious health problems, including trouble breathing, asthma attacks, and lung damage. Everyone can be affected, but sensitive groups such as people with lung disease, older adults, people who are pregnant, children, and those who spend a lot of time outdoors are at greater risk.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...To help keep indoor air clean when air quality is poor: 00
* Keep windows and doors closed * Run your air conditioner and/or an air purifier * Do not use whole house fans or swamp coolers that bring in outside air if you have other methods to stay cool * Avoid other sources of pollution such as fireplaces, candles, incense, and grilling
To help minimize outdoor ozone air pollution levels:
* Limit the use of gasoline powered lawn and garden equipment until evening hours * Try to delay trips to the 00gas station and the use of household chemicals until the evening
entry.cap:areaDesc: Calabasas and Agoura Hills; Eastern San Fernando Valley; Eastern San Gabriel Mountains; Interstate 5 Corridor; Los Angeles County Inland Coast including Downtown Los Angeles; Los Angeles County San Gabriel Valley; Santa Clarita Valley; Santa Susana Mountains; Western San Fernando Valley; Western San Gabriel Mountains and Highway 14 Corridor

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued July 9 at 1:49PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Thursday into Friday, an impactful frontal system with an associated weak to moderate Atmospheric River, primarily aimed at the southern Panhandle, will move over southeast Alaska. This system will bring moderate to heavy rainfall and strong winds to a widespread area. The heaviest precipitation looks to focus over the southern panhandle with 2 inches of rain in 24 hours. Around southern Baranof Island and at higher elevations, rain totals around or greater than 3 inches are possible in 24 hours. The heaviest of this rain will be Thursday evening with rain rates of 0.1 to 0.15 inches per hour. Isolated areas could see greater than 0.2 inches per hour. A Flood Advisory has also been issued for Ward Lake near Ketchikan.
Winds over the eastern Gulf, Clarence Strait, and near Dixon Entrance will reach gale force of 35 to 40 kts as the front pushes through Thursday. Wind gusts up to 45 to 50 kts are possible near Kayak Island Thursday afternoon. Land areas in the southern panhandle will experience wind gusts up to 40 mph.
entry.cap:areaDesc: City and Borough of Sitka; Prince of Wales Island; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island

cap:parameter.value: HEAVY RAIN POTENTIAL PRIMARILY FOR SOUTHERN PANHANDLE THURSDAY INTO FRIDAY
